verses.text: At that time, declares the LORD, I will be the God of all the families of Israel, and they will be my people.
verses.comment: This verse repeats the covenant promise: 'I will be their God, they will be my people.' A foreshadowing of how God gathers his people under one community.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: The people who survived the sword found grace in the wilderness—Israel, when I went to give him rest.
verses.comment: ‘Grace in the wilderness’ recalls both the Exodus and God’s steadfast mercy through hardship.

verses.text: The LORD appeared to him from afar, saying, 'I have loved you with an everlasting love; therefore I have drawn you with loving-kindness.'
verses.comment: God’s everlasting love signals the unbreakable, divine initiative in salvation history.

verses.text: Again I will build you, and you shall be rebuilt, O virgin Israel! Again you will take up your tambourines and go out in the dances of those who rejoice.
verses.comment: 'O virgin Israel' points to spiritual renewal and holiness that God restores.

verses.text: Again you will plant vineyards on the hills of Samaria; farmers shall plant and enjoy the fruit.
verses.comment: Fruitfulness in the land is symbolic of God’s blessing and restoration.

verses.text: For there will be a day when watchmen will call out on the hill country of Ephraim, ‘Arise, let us go up to Zion, to the LORD our God.’
verses.comment: The call to Zion prefigures spiritual pilgrimage and unity of worship.

verses.text: For thus says the LORD: Sing aloud with gladness for Jacob, and shout for the chief of the nations; proclaim, give praise, and say, 'O LORD, save your people, the remnant of Israel.'
verses.comment: 'Remnant' emphasizes faithfulness among God’s people, a theme of spiritual survival.

verses.text: Behold, I will bring them from the land of the north, and gather them from the farthest parts of the earth. Among them the blind and the lame, the pregnant woman and her who is in labor, together — a great company, they will return here.
verses.comment: God's gathering is inclusive, reaching the weak and vulnerable, anticipating Messianic miracles.

verses.text: With weeping they will come, and with pleas for mercy I will lead them back; I will make them walk by brooks of water, on a straight path in which they will not stumble. For I am a father to Israel, and Ephraim is my firstborn.
verses.comment: God as ‘Father’ to Israel ties into themes of divine paternity, tracing forward to the meaning of sonship fulfilled in Christ (cf. Matt. 2:15).

verses.text: Hear the word of the LORD, O nations, and declare it in the distant isles: ‘He who scattered Israel will gather him, and keep him as a shepherd keeps his flock.’
verses.comment: Shepherd imagery foreshadows Jesus' claim as the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: For the LORD has redeemed Jacob and ransomed him from the hand of one stronger than he.
verses.comment: The notion of redemption is both a historic deliverance and a theological anticipation of final redemption.

verses.text: They will come and sing on the height of Zion, and they will be radiant over the goodness of the LORD—over the grain, the new wine, the oil, and the young of the flock and herd. Their life will be like a watered garden, and they shall never languish again.
verses.comment: 'Watered garden' symbolizes spiritual abundance and continual blessing.

verses.text: Then shall the young women rejoice in the dance, and the young men and the old shall be merry. I will turn their mourning into joy; I will comfort them, and I will give them gladness instead of sorrow.
verses.comment: The reversal from sorrow to joy echoes promises of restoration in both testaments.

verses.text: I will satisfy the priests with abundance, and my people will be filled with my goodness, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s gift to the priests reflects a focus on right worship—the people’s joy flows from God’s generosity through his ministers.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: A voice is heard in Ramah, mourning and bitter weeping. Rachel is weeping for her children; she refuses to be comforted for her children, because they are no more.
verses.comment: Matthew applies this to the massacre in Bethlehem, connecting prophecy and fulfillment in Christ’s early life.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: Restrain your voice from weeping, and your eyes from tears, for your work will be rewarded, declares the LORD. They will return from the land of the enemy.
verses.comment: 'Your work will be rewarded' - even suffering and loss are part of God’s redemptive plan.

verses.text: There is hope for your future, declares the LORD, and your children shall return to their own land.
verses.comment: God’s promise of hope centers on real, physical restoration, with spiritual implications for all God’s people.

verses.text: I have surely heard Ephraim grieving, 'You have disciplined me, and I was disciplined like an untrained calf; bring me back that I may be restored, for you are the LORD my God.'
verses.comment: Desire for restoration is a prime sign of genuine repentance and humility before God.

verses.text: For after I turned away, I repented; and after I was instructed, I struck my thigh in shame; I was ashamed and confounded, because I bore the disgrace of my youth.
verses.comment: The language of repentance highlights the depth of Israel’s spiritual healing.

verses.text: Is Ephraim my dear son? Is he a delightful child? For as often as I speak against him, I still remember him. Therefore my heart yearns for him; I will surely have mercy on him, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s deep, parental compassion is central. His mercy never fades, echoing Jesus’ parable of the prodigal son.

verses.text: Set up signposts, make landmarks; direct your mind to the highway, the way by which you went. Return, O virgin Israel, return to these your cities.
verses.comment: 'Set up signposts'—a call to visible, intentional return and the importance of memory in faith.

verses.text: How long will you wander, O faithless daughter? For the LORD has created a new thing on the earth: a woman will surround a man.
verses.comment: This enigmatic 'new thing' is mysterious and often linked to the virginal conception—a sign of God’s future work.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel: Once more they shall use these words in the land of Judah and its cities when I restore their fortunes: 'The LORD bless you, O habitation of righteousness, O holy hill!'
verses.comment: 'Habitation of righteousness' hints at the holiness of God’s future dwelling among his people.

verses.text: And Judah and all its cities shall dwell there together, the farmers and those who wander with flocks.
verses.comment: A vision of stable, harmonious life in the promised land.

verses.text: For I will refresh the weary soul, and satisfy every languishing spirit.
verses.comment: God meets the deepest needs of his people, a promise Jesus echoes.

verses.text: At this I awoke and looked, and my sleep was pleasant to me.
verses.comment: Jeremiah recognizes God’s message as a comfort even in the midst of trouble.

verses.text: Behold, days are coming, declares the LORD, when I will sow the house of Israel and the house of Judah with the seed of man and the seed of beast.
verses.comment: 'Sowing' shows God's future Fruitfulness and abundance for both people and land.

verses.text: And as I have watched over them to pluck up and break down, to overthrow, destroy, and bring disaster, so I will watch over them to build and to plant, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over judgment and renewal is absolute.

verses.text: In those days they will no longer say: ‘The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge.’
verses.comment: Each person bears personal responsibility before God—a preview of direct accountability emphasized in the new covenant.

verses.text: But each one will die for his own sin; each man who eats the sour grapes, his teeth will be set on edge.
verses.comment: Individual judgment replaces collective guilt—a mark of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: Behold, the days are coming, declares the LORD, when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah.
verses.comment: Central prophecy of a new, everlasting covenant, fulfilled by Christ at the Last Supper (see Hebrews 8).

verses.text: Not like the covenant that I made with their fathers on the day I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt—my covenant that they broke, though I was their husband, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Husband' language reveals God’s faithful, personal love, ultimately fulfilled in Christ's relationship with his people (cf. Eph. 5:25).

verses.text: But this is the covenant that I will make with the house of Israel after those days, declares the LORD: I will put my law within them, and I will write it on their hearts. And I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
verses.comment: Internalization of the law points toward the transformative work of the Holy Spirit and the sacraments.

verses.text: No longer shall each teach his neighbor and each his brother, saying, 'Know the LORD,' for they shall all know me, from the least of them to the greatest, declares the LORD. For I will forgive their iniquity, and I will remember their sin no more.
verses.comment: God’s forgiveness is total and transformative, a reality explicitly fulfilled in Christ's new covenant ministry.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD, who gives the sun for light by day and the fixed order of the moon and the stars for light by night, who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—the LORD of hosts is his name:
verses.comment: Emphasizes God as the Creator and the one who sustains all things.

verses.text: If this fixed order departs from before me, declares the LORD, then shall the offspring of Israel cease from being a nation before me forever.
verses.comment: God's covenant is as enduring as creation itself, underlining the perpetual nature of His promises.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD: If the heavens above can be measured, and the foundations of the earth searched out beneath, then I will also cast off all the offspring of Israel for all they have done, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: God's mercy has no limit—His promise of forgiveness stands forever, foreshadowing the universality of salvation.

verses.text: Behold, days are coming, declares the LORD, when the city shall be rebuilt for the LORD from the Tower of Hananel to the Corner Gate.
verses.comment: This rebuilding suggests both historical restoration and typological reference to the future new Jerusalem.

verses.text: And the measuring line shall go out farther, straight to the hill Gareb, and then turn to Goah.
verses.comment: Details of Jerusalem's expansion symbolize God’s faithfulness in keeping every promise.

verses.text: And the whole valley, the dead bodies and the ashes, and all the fields as far as the brook Kidron, to the corner of the Horse Gate toward the east, shall be holy to the LORD. It will never again be uprooted or overthrown forever.
verses.comment: Declares a time when all is made holy to God, a vision of perfect restoration and sanctification.
